{"comments": {"id": 27632, "count": 26, "talk_id": 6594}, "threadId": 27632, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "6594", "description": "Talent is universal, but opportunity isn't, says TED Fellow Christopher Ategeka. In this charming, hopeful talk, Ategeka tells his story of being orphaned at a young age -- and how being adopted gave him the chance to experience a new culture, acquire an education and live up to his full potential. \"We may not be able to solve the bigotry and the racism of this world today,\" Ategeka says, \"But certainly we can raise children to create a positive, inclusive, connected world full of empathy, love and compassion.\"", "event": "TEDGlobal 2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Christopher Ategeka: How adoption worked for me", "slug": "christopher_ategeka_how_adoption_worked_for_me", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3441", "slug": "christopher_ategeka", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Christopher", "lastname": "Ategeka", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Serial entrepreneur", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/5c8d85336941c66886ad6cffd5828b42a0c53c3c_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "TED Fellow Christopher Ategeka is on a mission to ensure a sustainable future for humanity and the planet.", "whylisten": "

Like Batman, Christopher Ategeka witnessed the death of both his parents as a child. He grew up with immense hardships but managed to navigate an experience that left him equipped with valuable skills.

Ategeka is a serial entrepreneur, engineer and a pioneer in the unintended consequences of technologies ("UCOT") movement. He is the founder and Managing Director at LyfBase, the world's first center for the unintended consequences of technology. Ategeka coined and popularized the term "UCOT" (unintended consequences of technology) in the tech sector and the concept of "UCOT" evangelism. Before that, he founded Health Access Corps, a non-profit that works to establish sustainable health care systems on the African continent. He has been invited to speak at the Clinton Global Initiative and United Nations, and he's won many international awards for his work; he was named a 2016 World Economic Forum Young Global Leader and a 2017 TED Fellow. His work has been featured in many major media publications both locally and internationally such as BBC, Forbes, and NPR. He holds a Bachelor’s of Science, and Master’s of Science in Mechanical Engineering from the University of California, Berkeley.

Like Batman, Christopher Ategeka witnessed the death of both his parents as a child. He grew up with immense hardships but managed to navigate an experience that left him equipped with valuable skills.

Ategeka is a serial entrepreneur, engineer and a pioneer in the unintended consequences of technologies ("UCOT") movement. He is the founder and Managing Director at LyfBase, the world's first center for the unintended consequences of technology. Ategeka coined and popularized the term "UCOT" (unintended consequences of technology) in the tech sector and the concept of "UCOT" evangelism. Before that, he founded Health Access Corps, a non-profit that works to establish sustainable health care systems on the African continent. He has been invited to speak at the Clinton Global Initiative and United Nations, and he's won many international awards for his work; he was named a 2016 World Economic Forum Young Global Leader and a 2017 TED Fellow. His work has been featured in many major media publications both locally and internationally such as BBC, Forbes, and NPR. He holds a Bachelor’s of Science, and Master’s of Science in Mechanical Engineering from the University of California, Berkeley.

author: Christopher_Ategeka;
title: How adoption worked for me

aws-transcripts.transcript: how many of you attired of seeing celebrities adopting kids from the African continent? Well, it's not that old bad. I was adopted. I grew up in rural Uganda, most both my pants when I was very, very young when my parents passed. Experienced all the negative effects off poverty from homelessness, eating out of trash piles, you name it. But my life changed when I got accepted into an orphanage through one of those sponsor and often programs always sponsored and given an opportunity to acquire an education. I started over in Uganda. I went through school and there were these particular program worked. You finished high school, and after high school, you go learn a trade to become a cap Inter a mechanic or something along those lines. My case? Well, it was a little different. The sponsor family that was sending these $25 a month to this orphanage to sponsor me, which never I've never met them, said, Well, I would like to send you to college instead. Oh, it gets better And they said, if you get the paperwork, we'll send you to school in America instead. So with their help, I went to the embassy and apply for the visa. I got the visa. I remember this day like it was yesterday, I walked out of the embassy with this piece of paper in my hand. I hope in my step smile on my face knowing that my life is about to change. I went home that night and I slept with my passport because I'm afraid that someone might steal it. I couldn't fall asleep. I kept feeling it. I had a better idea for security.
